title: Red Hot Chili Peppers Discography Start
description:
Red Hot Chili Peppers - Under the Covers
 Acollection of covers by the Red Hot Chili Peppers-- mostly previously released-- blending studio and live recordings, "Under the Covers" makes for a unique and fun portrait of the band.

The Peppers are a fearless cover band, tackling everything from Hank Williams to Robert Johnson to Jimi Hendrix to Sly and the Family Stone without flinching. One thing that can be said about them is that they make everything their own-- even though this was recorded over a span of eight years, there&#039;s a remarkable sense of consistency to the sound and the music, with everything being assimulateed into the Chili Peppers&#039; funk/punk sound-- Dylan&#039;s "Subterranean Homesick Blues" sits comfortably next to Stevie Wonder&#039;s "Higher Ground". There&#039;s a remarkably high level of consistency. But more importantly, it&#039;s still really quite listenable. 

1. They&#039;re Red Hot 
2. Fire 
3. Subterranean Homesick Blues 
4. Higher Ground 
5. If You Want Me To Stay 
6. Why Don&#039;t You Love Me 
7. Tiny Dancer (Live) 
8. Castles Made Of Sand (Live) 
9. Dr. Funkenstein (Live) 
10. Hollywood (Africa) 
11. Search And Destroy 
12. Higher Ground (Daddy-O Mix) 
13. Hollywood (Africa) (Extended Dance Mix) 

         
 Red Hot Chili Peppers : Greatest Hits
 ALBUM HIGHLIGHTS : The Modern Rock #1s are "Give It Away," "Soul To Squeeze," "My Friends," "Californication," "Otherside" and "By The Way" (also Top 40 Pop). The Top 20s are "Higher Ground" and "Suck My Kiss." Red Hot Chili Peppers: Greatest Hits (includes "Save the Population" a track not on any other album)

 Out in L.A. - Red Hot Chili Peppers
 Long out of print in the U.S.! Out In L.A. is a virtual alternate audio history of the band, focusing on non-album tracks and remixed and alternate versions of tracks not normally included on RHCP compilations. For starters, six of the songs are unavailable on any of their albums in any form (&#039;Blues For Meister&#039;, &#039;You Always Sing The Same&#039;, &#039;Stranded&#039;, &#039;Flea Fly&#039;, &#039;What It Is&#039; and the seasonal favorite &#039;Deck The Halls&#039;). Also featured are remixes of &#039;Higher Ground&#039;, &#039;Hollywood Africa&#039;, &#039;If You Want Me To Stay&#039; and &#039;Behind The Sun&#039;, plus live versions of &#039;Castles Made Of Sand&#039;, &#039;Special Secret Song Inside&#039;, and &#039;F.U.&#039;. This CD even contains demo versions of &#039;Get Up And Jump&#039;, &#039;Out In LA&#039; and &#039;Police Helicopter&#039; amongst others! A treasure trove of RHCP gems at your fingertips! EMI.



1. Higher Ground (12&#039; Vocal Mix)

 What Hits? - Red Hot Chili Peppers
 An overview of the Red Hot Chili Peppers&#039; formative 1984 to 1989 stint with EMI Records, What Hits? contains plenty of hits, including their first truly huge success, "Under the Bridge," from their 1991 debut on Warner Bros., Blood Sugar Sex Magic. Other highlights here, including 1990&#039;s "Show Me Your Soul" (which proves the band learned plenty from working with George Clinton on 1985&#039;s Freaky Styley), their superb cover of Stevie Wonder&#039;s "Higher Ground," and the feel-good funk of "Behind the Sun," show the Peppers paved the way for a school of alt bands who melded funk with rock riffs. There are plenty other less-celebrated moments from the Peppers&#039; early days that shine on their own, and only a few self-indulgent clunkers (what drove them to such a dismal performance of Jimi Hendrix&#039;s "Fire"?). This collection will suffice for the casual fan who needs a quick intro to the Peppers&#039; history.

1. Higher Ground 
2. Fight like A Brave 
3. Behind The Sun 
4. Me & My Friends 
5. Backwoods 
6. True Men Don&#039;t Kill Coyotes

 Stadium Arcadium - Red Hot Chili Peppers
 Stadium Arcadium is the ninth studio album by alternative rock band Red Hot Chili Peppers, released on May 5, 2006 on Warner Bros. Records. It sold 442,000 copies in the U.S. in the first week and debuted at #1 on the Billboard 200.[1] The album produced five hit singles: "Dani California", "Snow ((Hey Oh))", "Desecration Smile", "Hump De Bump", and "Tell Me Baby". According to frontman Anthony Kiedis, Stadium Arcadium was originally scheduled to be a trilogy of albums each released six months apart, but was eventually condensed into a double album.


All songs written by Red Hot Chili Peppers

 By the Way - Red Hot Chili Peppers
 By the Way is the eighth studio album by American alternative rock band Red Hot Chili Peppers, released on July 9, 2002 on Warner Bros. Records. It sold over 282,000 copies in the first week, and peaked at #2 on the Billboard 200. The singles from the album included "By the Way", "The Zephyr Song", "Can&#039;t Stop", "Dosed" and "Universally Speaking". The lyrical subject matter vocalist Anthony Kiedis addresses in By the Way is a divergence from previous Chili Peppers albums, with Kiedis taking a more candid and reflective approach to his lyricism.
All songs written by Red Hot Chili Peppers unless otherwise stated

 Music Californication - Red Hot Chili Peppers
 
Californication is the seventh studio album by American alternative rock band Red Hot Chili Peppers, released on June 8, 1999 on Warner Bros. Records. Produced by Rick Rubin, Californication marked the return of John Frusciante, who had previously appeared on Mother&#039;s Milk and Blood Sugar Sex Magik, to replace Dave Navarro as the band&#039;s guitarist. Frusciante&#039;s return was credited with changing the band&#039;s sound altogether. The record was a notable shift in style from what was produced with Navarro. The album&#039;s subject material incorporated various sexual innuendos commonly associated with the band, and introduced themes of lust, death, contemplations of suicide, and drugs.


All songs written by Red Hot Chili Peppers.
